content.body: zcorpan: I see. Hmm, I think I dislike the idea of no line breaks. IMO it makes the source way harder to read and edit :/ I haven't looked at the output of your PR yet since I'd have to check it out locally first, but that would be my initial opinion.
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: I see. Hmm, I think I dislike the idea of no line breaks. IMO it makes the source way harder to read and edit :/ I haven't looked at the output of your PR yet since I'd have to check it out locally first, but that would be my initial opinion.

content.body: You just gotta turn on word-wrapping in your editor and it's nice, IMO...
while reading the standard, I stumbled upon slots and couldn't understand one thing
what is oldValue here: https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#slot-name ( just below this link u will find attribute change steps )
* while reading the DOM standard, I stumbled upon slots and couldn't understand one thing

m.new_content.body: while reading the DOM standard, I stumbled upon slots and couldn't understand one thing

content.body: Does following the link to https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-element-attributes-change-ext clarify it for you?

If not, you might need to follow the call sites backward, by clicking on the bolded definition of "attribute change steps" and looking at where it's called from. (And then where its callers are called from...)

Dominic Farolino: Most editors have a soft wrapping feature, but don't have an easy way to search for text across lines. But I understand that folks have different preferences. I think a benefit of no wrapping is that contributors don't need to run a formatting script as part of development.
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino: Most editors have a soft wrapping feature, but don't have an easy way to search for text across lines. But I understand that folks have different preferences. I think a benefit of no wrapping is that contributors don't need to run a formatting script as part of development.
